metadata.case_name: Appellant (Purchaser of properties) v. Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi

facts.text: Sudhir Kumar Mitter (second respondent) was owner of two houses: No. 86/1 Cornwallis Street and No. 7-C Kirti Mitter Lane, Calcutta.
On May 19, 1934, Sudhir Kumar Mitter executed a mortgage for Rs. 3,000 over the said houses in favour of Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi (first respondent).
Sm. Nirmala Sundari Dassi instituted Suit No. 158 of 1935 on the mortgage and obtained a preliminary decree on March 8, 1935.
Registrar's report dated July 23, 1935 found Rs. 3,914-6-6 due, and final decree passed on April 20, 1936.
First respondent took no steps to draw up the decree for nearly 18 years, as required under r. 27 ch. 16 Original Side Rules of Calcutta High Court.
On May 12, 1952, Sudhir Kumar Mitter sold both houses to the appellant for Rs. 60,000, utilised largely for discharging prior mortgages; deed recites properties sold free of all encumbrances.
On February 17, 1954, first respondent obtained ex parte order under r. 27 to draw up and complete the decree.
First respondent filed final decree on April 29, 1954 and commenced execution proceedings for sale.
Sudhir Kumar Mitter objected to execution as barred by limitation; Registrar made special report under ch. 26 r. 50.
P.B. Mukharji J. held execution not barred by limitation (judgment reported as Nirmala Sundari v. Sudhir Kumar, AIR 1955 Cal 484).
Sudhir Kumar Mitter preferred Appeal No. 152 of 1955 against P.B. Mukharji J.'s judgment, still pending.

On July 25, 1956, appellant applied to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955, alleging purchase free of encumbrances, execution barred, second respondent acting on her behalf but now colluding.
Respondents opposed, stating settlement at Rs. 17,670, fair and binding on appellant.
Calcutta High Court (Chakravarti C.J. and Lahiri J.) dismissed application by order dated August 6, 1956.
High Court rejected certificate under Art. 133 for appeal to Supreme Court.
Supreme Court granted special leave under Art. 136.
Appellant claims amount under decree not exceeding Rs. 6,000; respondents claim Rs. 17,670 including disputed interest and costs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant's application to be brought on record as appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955 is maintainable under O. 22 r. 10 CPC or alternatively under s. 146 CPC.
Whether execution of the 1936 decree is barred by limitation.
Quantum due under the decree, including disputed interest and costs.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application maintainable under O. 22 r. 10 CPC as suit pending until decree drawn up in 1954, transfer in 1952 pendente lite.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O. 22 r. 10 CPC; Lakshan Chunder Dey v. Sm. Nikunjamani Dassi (1923) 27 CWN 755

petitioner_arguments.text: Execution proceedings barred by limitation; properties purchased free of encumbrances; second respondent acted on her behalf but now colluding; amount due not exceeding Rs. 6,000.
Entitled under s. 146 CPC as claiming under second respondent, right to continue appeal filed by him.

respondent_arguments.text: O. 22 r. 10 not applicable as no application in original court during suit pendency, and transfer before appeal filed.
Settlement with second respondent at Rs. 17,670 fair, bona fide, binding on appellant; application not maintainable.

court_reasoning.text: O. 22 r. 10 strictly not applicable as transfer not during pendency of appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer prior to filing of appeal No. 152 of 1955.

court_reasoning.text: Application maintainable under s. 146 CPC; appeal is a 'proceeding'; 'claiming under' includes assignment; entitled to continue appeal filed by assignor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 146 facilitates rights by devolution/assignment, to be construed liberally.

court_reasoning.text: Substantial questions on limitation, amount due (Rs. 17,670 disputed, includes contract rate interest, other costs); appellant as purchaser vitally interested, justice requires opportunity to protect rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: P.B. Mukharji J. noted substantial questions of law.

court_reasoning.text: Cited precedents approve s. 146 application: Sitharamaswami v. Lakshmi Narasimha; Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co.; Muthiah Chettiar v. Oovinddoss Krishnadass; Moidin Kutty v. Doraiswami.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transferee can continue proceedings initiated by transferor.

holdings.text: Appellant's application maintainable under s. 146 CPC; entitled to be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
Set aside High Court order dated August 6, 1956.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshan Chunder Dey v. Sm. Nikunjamani Dassi
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit pending until decree drawn up.
Appeal is proceeding under s. 146; 'claiming under' includes O.22 r.10 cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Transferee entitled under s.146 even if not under specific rules.
Assignee can continue execution by transferor.
P.B. Mukharji J.'s judgment on limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs substitution/continuation by person claiming under another; appeal as proceeding.

statutes_cited.name: Original Side Rules, Calcutta High Court
statutes_cited.relevance: Drawing up decree; special report on limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave and certificate for appeal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Calcutta High Court order dated August 6, 1956 dismissing appellant's application; directed that appellant be brought on record as additional appellant in Appeal No. 152 of 1955.
outcome.relief_granted: Brought on record as additional appellant.

key_quotes.text: "Section 146 provides that save as otherwise provided by the Code, any proceeding which can be taken by a person may also be taken by any person claiming under him."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "That section was introduced... with the object of facilitating the exercise of rights by persons in whom they come to be vested by devolution or assignment, and being a beneficent provision should be construed liberally."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains liberal interpretation of s.146 CPC.

key_quotes.text: "Justice requires that she should be given an opportunity to protect her rights."
key_quotes.speaker: court
